questions.question_text: Users on a LAN segment are reporting a loss of connectivity to network services. The client PCs have been assigned with 169.254.X.X IP addresses. Which of the following IP address schemas is being utilized?

discussion.content: APIPA stands for Automatic Private IP Addressing (APIPA). It is a feature or characteristic in operating systems (eg. Windows) which enables computers to self-configure an IP address and subnet mask automatically when their DHCP(Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol) server isnâ€™t reachable. The IP address range for APIPA is (169.254.0.1 to 169.254.255.254) having 65, 534 usable IP addresses, with the subnet mask of 255.255.0.0.

comments.content: no it not.....it's 169! Why is this even up for debate? Pervert!
Funny how people come here to learn, Kewlboy is providing a great service for helping others. He makes one typing error and you gun it for him?!? Shows what kind of person you are POES!!!

discussion.content: anything 196.254 is APIPA!!! remember it by the funny number (69 nice )

questions.question_text: A network administrator has created a new VLAN for the server and clients within the accounting department and wants to outline how it integrates with the existing network. Which of the following should the administrator create?

discussion.content: A logical network diagram describes the way information flows through a network. Therefore, logical network diagrams typically show subnets (including VLAN IDs, masks, and addresses), network devices like routers and firewalls, and routing protocols.
VLAN= VIRTUAL local area network therefore not something physical

I thought as much initially, but it hit me. VLAN's are not physical but rather virtual, and even though we can infer VLAN's from IP addresses on the physical diagram I suspect that logical diagrams will state outright the existence of VLANs on a network.
People who have worked with diagrams please chime in.
A logical diagram doesnt show VLANS or IP addressing?

questions.question_text: Which of the following would indicate that a circuit speed should be increased?

discussion.content: Low Latency and Low bandwidth consumption are actually GOOD for a network, Read the question guys LMFAO!!!!
If you know how packet loss happens, you'll know it's the answer.

Pretty sure the answer is B. if you have low bandwidth consumption you would want to increase the speed of that segment. If you have high packet loss that segment is moving faster than it should, an increase of speed would be no bueno.

comments.content: LMAOO!!! i thought the same exact thing... till i read your comment
I was in this same boat, lol.
Sorry ignore that, didn't realise low latency is good. Duh

discussion.content: Doesn't Latency make more sense, should the answer be A ?

comments.content: I like the comment "Thanks, dolor for your useless comment."

discussion.content:
Thanks, dolor for your useless comment.
B is correct.

On an Ethernet connection, a duplex mismatch is a condition where two connected devices operate in different duplex modes, that is, one operates in half duplex while the other one operates in full duplex. The effect of a duplex mismatch is a link that operates inefficiently.

Camera streaming is off, half duplex is used for camera to DVR. Steaming is on = Full duplex
A duplex mismatch will cause data transmission collisions, slowing down transmissions.

questions.question_text: A technician has installed an older IP camera as a temporary replacement for a recently failed newer one. The technician notices that when the camera's video stream is off, the ping roundtrip time between the camera and the network DVR is consistently less than 1ms without dropped packets. When the camera video stream is turned on, the ping roundtrip time increases dramatically, and network communication is slow and inconsistent. Which of the following is MOST likely the issue in this scenario?

discussion.content: "signature" was the word that made me chose the right answer.
They should just say hashing thought they meant physical security for asec.
